statement.tex: %text Find the direction rations of the normal to the plane which passes through the points $(1, 0, 0)$ and $(0, 1, 0)$ and makes angle $\dfrac{\pi}{4}$ with the plane $x+y=3$. Also find the equation of the plane. %

options.tex: %text If the plane $Ax+By+Cz-D=0$ makes an angle $\frac{\pi}{4}$ with the plane $x+y-3=0$ then, % \begin{align} &\left\vert\dfrac{A+B}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}\right\vert=1 \\ \implies &2AB=C^2 \end{align}

reason.tex:
%text Angle between any two planes is given by, % \begin{align} \cos\theta=\left\vert\dfrac{A_1A_2+B_1B_2+C_1C_2} {\sqrt{A_1^2+B_1^2+C_1^2}\sqrt{A_2^2+B_2^2+C_2^2}} \right\vert \end{align} \\
%text Substituting $A_1=A$, $B_1=B$, $C_1=C$ ($A_1x+b_1y+C_1z+D=0$), $A_2=1$, $B_2=1$, $C_2=0$ ($x+y-3=0$) and $\theta=\dfrac{\pi}{4}$, we get, % \begin{align} &\left\vert\dfrac{A+B}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}\sqrt{2}}\right\vert= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\\ \implies &\left\vert\dfrac{A+B}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}\right\vert=1 \\ \implies &A^2+B^2+2AB=A^2+B^2+C^2 \\ \implies &2AB=C^2 \end{align}

%text $(1, 0, 0)$ lies on $Ax+By+Cz+D=0$ therefore % \begin{align} A(1)+B(0)+C(0)+D=0 \implies A+D=0 \quad(1) \end{align} \\ %text $(0, 1, 0)$ lies on $Ax+By+Cz+D=0$ therefore % \begin{align} A(0)+B(1)+C(0)+D=0 \implies B+D=0 \quad(2) \end{align} \\ %text From $(1)$ and $(2)$, we get, $A=B=-D$ %

options.tex: %text If for plane $Ax+By+Cz+D=0$, $2AB=C^2$ and $A=B=-D$, then its equation is $x+y\pm\sqrt{2}z-1=0$ and the direction ratios are $1, 1, \sqrt{2}$ or $1, 1, -\sqrt{2}$. %
%text If for plane $Ax+By+Cz+D=0$, $2AB=C^2$ and $A=B=-D$, then its equation is $2x+2y\pm\sqrt{2}z-1=0$ and the direction ratios are $2, 2, \sqrt{2}$ or $2, 2, -\sqrt{2}$. %
